section.description: Alpha Anywhere's Enterprise software gives you the ability to read and write to back-end database products in a manner similar to the way you would read and write to an Alpha Anywhere table. The term "back-end database" refers to the following ODBC compatible database products which support the SQL query language.

section.title: Supported Database Types

case.title: FlexQuarters QODBC
case.description: Uses the QODBC driver. Version 6 recommended. Requires installation of the driver.

case.title: IBM DB2
case.description: Tested on versions as old as DB2 version 8.1. Requires installation of the DB2 client.

case.title: InterSystems Cache
case.description: Requires both an installed ODBC driver and a data source name definition (DSN).

case.title: Microsoft Access
case.description: Supported for versions from Office 2000 onward. Requires installation of the Microsoft ODBC driver (MDAC).

case.title: Microsoft Excel
case.description: Tested on versions as old as Office 2000. Requires installation of the Microsoft ODBC driver (MDAC).

case.title: Microsoft SQL Server
case.description: Tested on versions as old as SQL Server version 7. Requires installation of the Microsoft ODBC driver (MDAC).

case.title: MySQL
case.description: Tested on versions as old as 3.23.42. No client software installation required.

case.title: Oracle XE, 9i, 10g
case.description: Tested on versions as old as Oracle 9i. Does not require manual installation of the client drivers. May require an additional download (which is automated) of the Oracle Thin Client software the first time the user connects to Oracle if the client software is not already installed on the user's system.

case.title: Oracle Lite (9i, 10g)
case.description: Tested on versions as old as Oracle 9i Lite. Requires installation of the Oracle Lite client software. See SQL_InstallOracleLiteFunctions().

case.title: Sybase Adaptive Server Enterprise
case.description: Requires both an installed ODBC driver and a data source name definition (DSN).

case.title: Sybase SQLAnywhere
case.description: Requires both an installed ODBC driver and a data source name definition (DSN).

section.note: MDAC is often already available on a system because Microsoft Office or some other software is installed. This is not guaranteed.

section.title: Connecting to Unlisted ODBC Databases
section.description: For any database not listed above that provides an ODBC driver:

step.description: Install the driver on each machine to access the database.
In the connection string dialog, select ODBC as your vendor and ODBC as your syntax.
Most functions will work without any special coding on your part.

section.note: Data definition syntax tends to vary more in SQL databases. Creating a table using the SQL::TableInfo data object may not work. In such cases, you will need to code the syntax to create the table and execute it directly.

section.title: Listing Installed APIs and Syntaxes
section.description: To see a complete list of drivers installed, execute the SQL::Connection::ListAPIs() function in the Interactivewindow as follows:
section.example: dim c as sql::connection ?c.ListAPIs() = ADONET Access CouchDB DB2 Espresso Excel Google MongoDB MySQL ODBC Oracle OracleLite Paradox PostgreSQL PostgresPlus QuickBooks QuickBooksOnline SQLServer StaticJSON odata salesforce

section.description: To see a complete list of syntaxes installed, execute the SQL::Connection::ListSyntaxes() function in the Interactivewindow as follows:
section.example: dim c as sql::connection ?c.ListSyntaxes() = Access Cache DB2 DB2i DB2iV4 ElevateDB Excel FoundationDB FoxPro Generic MySQL ODBC Oracle OracleCaseSensitive OracleLite Paradox Pervasive PostgreSQL PostgresPlus QuickBooks SharePoint SQLAnywhere SQLite SQLAzure SQLServer Sybase
